field_reports.description: The Earthquake with a magnitude of 6.1 and with a depth of 11 kilometers struck the Sındırgı District of Balikesir Province in western Turkey at 19:53 (Turkish Local Time), causing the death of one person and the injury of 52 people. Affecting 8 neighbourhoods at the district center of Sındırgı and  68 neighbourhoods in its rural areas near the epicenter, it caused the demolition of 16 buildings, out of which 12 were not habitable during the Earthquake.  The Search and Rescue Teams from the National Disaster Management Agency were operational with 781 staff, 170 vehicles, and  rescued 4 people from under the rubble. MoH  mobilized 258 staff and 76 vehicles for medevac and medical response. The Logistics Centers in Balıkesir, Bursa, and Manisa were operational and ready to send  46,540 family-type tents to the affected area. The situaiton is returning to normalcy while damage assessment teams are working in the field.

results.name: TUR: Earthquake - 08-2025 - Sındırgı Earthquake
results.summary: The Earthquake with a magnitude of 6.1 struck the Sındırgı District of Balikesir Province in western Turkey at 19:53 (Turkish Local Time), causing the death of one person and the injury of 52 people. Affecting 68 neighborhoods in rural areas near the epicenter, it caused the demolition of 16 buildings, out of which 12 were not habitable during the Earthquake.  The Search and Rescue Teams from the National Disaster Management Agency have been operational with 781 staff, 170 vehicles, and have rescued 4 people from under the rubble. MoH has mobilized 258 staff and 76 vehicles for medevac and medical response. The Logistics Centers in Balıkesir, Bursa, and Manisa are operational and ready to send  46,540 family-type tents to the affected area.

field_reports.description:
In late June and early July 2025, large-scale wildfires broke out across several provinces in western Türkiye, particularly affecting the Aegean region, including İzmir, Çanakkale, and Balıkesir. The fires, fueled by strong winds, high temperatures, and low humidity, spread rapidly across forested and rural areas, causing significant environmental and social impacts.

Approximately 50,000 people were evacuated from their homes as a precautionary measure, with around 42,000 people displaced in Seferihisar district alone. At least 46 individuals were hospitalized due to smoke inhalation and other fire-related injuries, with one reported in critical condition. Although no official fatalities have been confirmed, the fires caused considerable damage to residential areas, agricultural lands, and livestock.

The situation has placed pressure on local response capacities, and multiple firefighting teams, aerial support units, and humanitarian organizations—including Türk Kızılay—have been mobilized. Türk Kızılay has been actively providing hot meals, water, and psychosocial support to affected communities and response personnel.

The affected population includes vulnerable groups such as the elderly, persons with chronic illnesses, and low-income rural families, many of whom have lost access to shelter, livelihoods, and basic services. The risk of recurring fires remains high due to ongoing heatwaves and dry conditions.

results.name: TUR: Fire - 06-2025 - Nationwide Wildfires
results.summary:

Approximately 50,000 people were evacuated from their homes as a precautionary measure, with around 42,000 people displaced in Seferihisar district alone. At least 46 individuals were hospitalized due to smoke inhalation and other fire-related injuries, with one reported in critical condition. field_reports.description:
On 23 April 2025, starting at 12:49 PM, multiple earthquakes struck the Marmara Region of Türkiye, with the strongest registering a magnitude of 6.2 on the Richter Scale. The epicenter was located near the central point of the Marmara Sea. The provinces affected include İstanbul, Tekirdağ, Yalova, Bursa, and Balıkesir. İstanbul, home to more than 20 million people, is among the most impacted areas.
According to field assessments conducted by relevant authorities and evaluations of reports received through the 112 Emergency Call Center, no casualties or major structural damage have been reported so far. However, many residents remain outside their homes due to fear of aftershocks.
The Ministry of Health has reported that 151 people were injured due to panic-related incidents. These individuals are receiving medical treatment in hospitals, and none are in critical condition.
It has been confirmed that no buildings have collapsed as a result of the earthquakes. However, preliminary assessments have led to the evacuation of 9 buildings deemed structurally unsafe. In addition, damage assessments are ongoing in all public buildings, including schools and government offices.

results.name: TUR: Earthquake - 04-2025 - Marmara Region - Istanbul
results.summary:
Multiple earthquakes, the largest with a magnitude of 6.2 Richter Scale, occurred in the Marmara Region of Türkiye starting at 12:49 PM on 23 April 2025.

The epicentre of the earthquakes is approximately at the central point of the Marmara Sea. Istanbul has a population of more than 20 million people.

As of this report, no casualties, injuries, or material damage are reported. People in the region remain outside their houses because of the fear of continued earthquakes.

The National Disaster Response Plan has been activated. Turkish Red Crescent is the cluster lead in nutrition (mass feeding) and is prepared to respond. 

The National Disaster and Crisis Management Center of the Turkish Red Crescent in Ankara, along with those in the region (Istanbul, Anatolia and Europe, Duzce, Kırklareli, Ankara DM Centers) and Branches in Istanbul and the region have been mobilised. 

DM teams and volunteers are deployed to serve food to people with a capacity of and 100 mobile catering vehicles.

field_reports.description: In February 2025, Turkey was affected by a cold wave originating from Siberia. This caused a significant drop in temperatures and heavy snowfall across the country. In particular, Istanbul experienced 3-4 days of continuous snowfall, covering the city in white. The Turkish State Meteorological Service issued a yellow-coded heavy snowfall warning for 20 provinces on February 20, 2025. This cold wave reached the Mediterranean coast, and snowfall in many regions accumulated on the ground, disrupting transportation.
field_reports.summary: TUR: Cold Wave - 02-2025 - Nationwide Heavy Snowfall

results.name: TUR: Cold Wave - 02-2025 - Nationwide Heavy Snowfall
results.summary: In February 2025, Turkey was affected by a cold wave originating from Siberia. This caused a significant drop in temperatures and heavy snowfall across the country. In particular, Istanbul experienced 3-4 days of continuous snowfall, covering the city in white. The Turkish State Meteorological Service issued a yellow-coded heavy snowfall warning for 20 provinces on February 20, 2025. field_reports.description: On January 21, 2025, a fire broke out at the Grand Kartal Hotel in Bolu, Turkey. The fire, which started around 03:30 AM, quickly spread due to the wooden interior. At least 79 people lost their lives, and 51 others were injured. The hotel was accommodating 238 guests at the time. Emergency services responded with 30 fire trucks and 28 ambulances. An investigation into the cause of the fire is ongoing. Various actors responded to the fire, including government agencies, NGOs, and international organizations. The Ministry of Interior initiated a swift response and launched an investigation, while the Disaster and Emergency Management Authority (AFAD) assisted in evacuation efforts. The Turkish Red Crescent provided those affected food, water, and shelter. Local and national health services transported the injured to hospitals for immediate medical attention.

results.name: TUR: Fire - 01-2025 - in Bolu/Kartalkaya
results.summary: On January 21, 2025, a fire broke out at the Grand Kartal Hotel in Bolu, Turkey. The fire, which started around 03:30 AM, quickly spread due to the wooden interior. At least 66 people lost their lives, and 51 others were injured. The hotel was accommodating 234 guests at the time. Emergency services responded with 30 fire trucks and 28 ambulances. An investigation into the cause of the fire is ongoing.

field_reports.description: On October 16, 2024, a 5.9 magnitude earthquake struck the Kale district of Malatya, with no fatalities reported. Following the quake, some individuals were injured due to jumping from heights, resulting in a total of 9 injuries. In total, 187 people were affected by the earthquake.

results.summary: On October 16, 2024, a 5.9 magnitude earthquake struck the Kale district of Malatya, with no fatalities reported. Following the quake, some individuals were injured due to jumping from heights, resulting in a total of 9 injuries. In total, 187 people were affected by the earthquake.

field_reports.description: A 5.6 magnitude earthquake occurred in the Sulusaray district of Tokat, causing five people to be injured as they panicked and tried to flee. According to the information received, the epicenter of the earthquake was in Tokat’s Sulusaray district, where five people were injured in various ways while trying to escape in panic due to the tremor. The injured were taken to the district state hospital for treatment.

field_reports.description:
On July 7, 2023, severe rainfall in the Western Black Sea region of Turkey caused widespread flooding and landslides, particularly affecting the provinces of Bartın, Düzce, and Zonguldak.

The disaster resulted in:

  • 11 fatalities
  • 58 injuries
  • Over 6,000 people affected, many of whom were forced to evacuate their homes.

Significant damage occurred to agricultural lands and infrastructure, with numerous houses and businesses submerged. Rescue and relief efforts were swiftly initiated to assist those impacted by the flooding.
field_reports.summary: TUR: Flood - 07-2023 - in Western Black Sea Flood

  • Over 6,000 people affected, many of whom were forced to evacuate their homes.

Significant damage occurred to agricultural lands and infrastructure, with numerous houses and businesses submerged. Rescue and relief efforts were swiftly initiated to assist those impacted by the flooding.

field_reports.description: A magnitude 7.7 earthquake occurred in Pazarcik, Kahramanmaras Türkiye followed by an earthquake of 7.6 in Elbistan, Kahramanmaras occurred the following day in the same region. This is the largest disaster of the century. Earthquakes affected the neighbouring provinces of Adıyaman, Kilis, Osmaniye, Gaziantep, Malatya, Şanlıurfa, Diyarbakır, Adana and Hatay, where around 14 million people reside.
field_reports.summary: TUR: Earthquake - 2023-02 - Situation Report I – Earthquake in Türkiye (2023-02-15)

field_reports.description:
According to the data from AFAD (Disaster and Emergency Management Presidency), an earthquake centered in Kahramanmaraş of 7.8 magnitude occurred at 04:17 A.M (01:17 GMT) and an earthquake of 7.6 magnitude occurred at 13:24 P.M (10:24 GMT) in Türkiye on February 6th 2023, more than 4.673 aftershocks at maximum level of 6.7 followed the initial earthquake.

The epicenter of the earthquake was Pazarcık district of Kahramanmaraş, and the earthquake occurred 7 km below the ground. The earthquake was also felt in neighboring cities of Adıyaman, Kilis, Şanlıurfa, Diyarbakır, Adana, Osmaniye, Gaziantep, Malatya, Batman, Bingöl, Elazığ, Mardin, Siirt, Şırnak, Van, Bitlis, Hakkari and Hatay provinces; and neighboring countries of Syria, Cyprus, Greece, Jordan, Lebanon, Iraq, Georgia and Armenia.

The Disaster and Emergency Management Presidency (AFAD) declared the level of earthquake as Level 4 within the scope of Türkiye Disaster Response Plan. In addition, AFAD announced that international assistance was called for in the field of urban search and rescue through the ERCC (Emergency Response Coordination Center) during the meetings with the Ministry of Foreign Affairs regarding the 7.8 magnitude earthquake.

AFAD reports states that 36.187 people lost their lives, 108.068 people were injured and 24.921 building were destroyed in 10 provinces.
field_reports.summary: TUR: Earthquake - 2023-02 - TUR: Earthquake - 2023-02 - Kahramanmaras Earthquake #2 (2023-02-06)

field_reports.description:
An earthquake of 7.4 magnitude was recorded at 04:17 in the Pazarcik district of Kahramanmaras in Turkey at 04:17 A.M. on February 6th 2023 and continued within 42 afterhocks at maximum level 6.6.

 

Earthquake; It was felt intensely in the surrounding provinces, especially in Kahramanmaras, Hatay, Osmaniye, Gaziantep, Sanliurfa, Diyarbakir, Malatya and Adana. Within the scope of the Turkey Disaster Response Plan, the level of the earthquake was declared as Level 4 by The Disaster and Emergency Management Presidency (AFAD).

 

At this time AFAD has reported at 08:00 am, 76 people lost their lifes, 440 people injured in all affected provinces. The process of damage detection is currently being fullfilled by AFAD and all related official organisations.

 

In with the AFAD and Ministry of Foreign Affairs, international assistance was called for in the field of urban search and rescue through the ERCC.

results.name: Türkiye : Earthquake - 2023-02
results.summary:
Turkish Red Crescent (TRC) is responsible for coordinating mass feeding services in the disaster area.

TRC maintains activity in 1,000 locations in the earthquake zone, providing aid, especially in remote areas with low accessibility.

Displacement: According to IOM, the estimated displaced within the earthquake-affected provinces is 2.7 million, of whom 1.1 million have evacuated to different Turkish provinces. As of 6 March, 214,000 buildings have collapsed or are heavily damaged. More than 1.9 million people have been provided with shelter in the form of tents, containers, and public buildings, including dormitories and sports halls. There are also informal camp settlements and rural settlements consisting of smaller villages in the 11 affected provinces where relief interventions are more difficult.

Basic Needs: Over one million earthquake survivors received a household support payment of 10,000 TRY from the Turkish Government. The Government will also provide 15,000 TRY to earthquake survivors who are moving to a new home. In an assessment of 290 key informants in Adiyaman, Hatay, Gaziantep, Kahramanmaras, and Kilis, 85 per cent of respondents said that they do not have a reliable source of income, stressing the need for cash.

Shelter: AFAD reports that 1,593,808 people have been given shelter within the earthquake-affected provinces, and 329,960 people have been given shelter in other provinces throughout Türkiye. Rental prices have increased.

Food: Ready-to-eat foods and hot meals continue to be needed. Out of 780 assessed displacement sites across the 11 provinces, key informants in 51 per cent of sites indicated that people purchase their own food. In 24 per cent of sites, key informants reported insufficient availability of baby foods.

WASH facilities remain a pressing need. A high need for hygiene and dignity kits has been reported, and 45 per cent of key informants in temporary accommodation sites indicated kits were unavailable.

Health: Among the priority concerns, as listed by WHO, are the provision of essential medicines, emergency kits and supplies, prevention of outbreaks and diseases, and access to mental health and psychosocial support. Another pressing health concern related to demolished buildings is asbestos, a material used in the construction of buildings before it was banned in 2010. It can cause serious illnesses (lung disease and cancer) when inhaled, and thus its handling requires centralized systematic management in the affected areas along with the use of specialised personal protective equipment.

Protection, Gender and Inclusion: According to UNFPA, access to safe deliveries and post-natal care is a major concern as many health facilities are damaged or services are disrupted. Additionally, there is a high need for mobile and temporary service units and sexual and reproductive health supplies in the affected regions.

See assessments, situation reports, information products, and appeal documents for more details.

field_reports.description:
On December 12, 2022, heavy rainfall in Kumluca, Antalya, led to severe flooding. The disaster resulted in:

  • 4 fatalities
  • 12 injuries
  • Approximately 1,000 people affected, with many homes and businesses submerged.

Significant damage occurred to infrastructure, prompting immediate search and rescue operations. Emergency response teams were deployed to assist those impacted by the flood.

field_reports.description: A 5.9 Mw earthquake has occured in Gölyaka, Turkey at 04:30 A.M. The earthquake has been effective in the nearby provinces including İstanbul and Ankara. There has been no losses of life, moderate and heavy damage has been reported so far. Information has been received that 30 people have been injured and are being treated. Electricity shortage is currently experienced in the area.

Electricity shortage is currently experienced in the area.

field_reports.description: An explosion occured on Friday October 14th inside a coal mine at 6 pm local time (5 pm CEST) in the town of Amasra in the Black Sea province of Bartin, Turkey. The explosion caused the death of of 41 miners and left eleven miners injured and hospitalised, while 58 others managed to get out of the mine on their own or were rescued unharmed. The mine was affected at two levels 300 and 350 metres below sea level. Friends and relatives stayed on site overnight, grimly awaiting on news of their loved ones.
field_reports.summary: TUR: Other - 2022-10 - Bartın Coal Mine Explosion

results.name: TUR: Other - 2022-10 - Bartın Coal Mine Explosion
results.summary: An explosion occured on Friday October 14th inside a coal mine at 6 pm local time (5 pm CEST) in the town of Amasra in the Black Sea province of Bartin, Turkey. The explosion caused the death of of 41 miners and left eleven miners injured and hospitalised, while 58 others managed to get out of the mine on their own or were rescued unharmed. The mine was affected at two levels 300 and 350 metres below sea level. Friends and relatives stayed on site overnight, grimly awaiting on news of their loved ones.

field_reports.description: Following excessive rainfall in the Western Black Sea region on 11 August 2021, flooding has occurred in the Ayancık district of Sinop, Ulus district of Bartın, Azvaday and Bozkurt districts of Kastamonu. According to information from the Disaster and Emergency Management Presidency (AFAD) of the Ministry of Interior of the Republic of Turkey, 68 persons in Kastamonu, 9 persons in Sinop, and 1 persons in Bartın have lost their lives, as a result of the flash floods. Treatment of 2 persons who have been wounded as a result of a bridge collapse continues. Post-disaster recovery and humanitarian efforts are ongoing in the affected regions.

field_reports.description: A total of 299 wildfires have started in 54 provinces across Turkey in the last 17 days. As of today, all wildfires across the country are under control. The fires have adversely affected forests and residential areas; thus, several neighbourhoods and villages have been evacuated. Many animals have perished amidst the fires. According to the most recent information received from the Disaster and Emergency Management Presidency (AFAD), a total of 9 people lost their lives due to wildfires.

While 267 of these fires have been controlled, 3 wildfires are still ravaging different areas in Antalya, Adana, Isparta, Mersin, Muğla, and Osmaniye. The fires have adversely affected forests and residential areas; thus, several neighbourhoods and villages have been evacuated. Many animals have perished amidst the fires. According to the most recent information received from the Disaster and Emergency Management Presidency (AFAD), a total of 9 people lost their lives due to wildfires.

field_reports.description:
A total of 180 wildfires have affected 38 different provinces in Turkey. The fires started on 28.07.2021 and continue to rage mainly in the Mediterranean and Aegean regions of Turkey. 12 wildfires are still continuing in the provinces of; Antalya, Aydın, Denizli, Isparta and Muğla. 

According to the Ministry of Health of the Republic of Turkey, a total of 8 people lost their lives due to wildfires.
The Ministry of Agriculture and Forestry, the Disaster and Emergency Management Authority (AFAD), Metropolitan and Local Municipalities as well as the Coast Guard, Gendarmerie and Police forces are devoting staff and resources to extinguish the ongoing wildfires. More than 5,250 expert personnel, 51 helicopters, 16 aircraft fire extinguishers, 850 mobile water tankers, 9 aerial reconnaissance drones as well as 850 heavy machinery and mobile water tankers of various kinds have been deployed to battle the raging fires. In addition the Coast Guard has deployed 520 personnel, 26 boats, 1 corvette class vessel, 3 specialist search and rescue teams as well as 1 helicopter to help the disaster response efforts. The Gendarmerie have deployed a total of 2,310 personnel, 317 vehicles and 4 helicopters while the Police Forces have set up mobile kitchens and made available a number of water cannon vehicles to extinguish the fires.     

The Disaster and Emergency Management Authority (AFAD) has stated that they have made available all state guest houses in the region in order to provide housing for those in need of shelter assistance. As a result, 1.332 persons have been provided shelter support. AFAD has stated there is a total capacity of 5.064 beds which remains on standby should any need arise. In addition, 557 family sized tents, 40 general use large scale tents, 204 container living units as well as 42 portable toilets have been deployed to the fire affected areas by AFAD.   

The Ministry of Environment and Urbanization officials are continuing damage assessment field work in the provinces which have been affected by the wildfires. 

The wildfire which affected the Ören district of Muğla and was in close proximity to the Kemerköy Thermal Power Plant, has subsequently been brought under control. 

According to the latest statements made by the Ministry of Health of the Republic of Turkey, 8 people have lost their lives as a result of the fires.

contacts.name: Anıl Türken
contacts.title: Acting Head of Humanitarian Policy and Advocacy

contacts.name: Kaan Saner
contacts.title: Director of International Policies and Partnerships

field_reports.description:
A total of 174 wildfires have affected 36 different provinces in Turkey. The fires started on 28.07.2021 and continue to rage mainly in the Mediterranean and Aegean regions of Turkey. The main provinces that continue to be affected are; Antalya, Muğla, Aydın, Isparta and Denizli. 

According to statements made by the Ministry of Agriculture and Forestry of the Republic of Turkey as well as the Director of Communications of the Presidency of the Republic of Turkey, Mr. Fahrettin ALTUN, on 04.08.2021, 161 of the wildfires in 34 provinces have been brought under control. 13 wildfires continue to impact 5 provinces.   

The Ministry of Agriculture and Forestry, the Disaster and Emergency Management Authority (AFAD), Metropolitan and Local Municipalities as well as the Coast Guard, Gendarmerie and Police forces are devoting staff and resources to extinguish the ongoing wildfires. More than 5,250 expert personnel, 51 helicopters, 16 aircraft fire extinguishers, 850 mobile water tankers, 9 aerial reconnaissance drones as well as 850 heavy machinery and mobile water tankers of various kinds have been deployed to battle the raging fires. In addition the Coast Guard has deployed 520 personnel, 26 boats, 1 corvette class vessel, 3 specialist search and rescue teams as well as 1 helicopter to help the disaster response efforts. The Gendarmerie have deployed a total of 2,310 personnel, 317 vehicles and 4 helicopters while the Police Forces have set up mobile kitchens and made available a number of water cannon vehicles to extinguish the fires.     

The Disaster and Emergency Management Authority (AFAD) has stated that they have made available all state guest houses in the region in order to provide housing for those in need of shelter assistance. As a result, 1.332 persons have been provided shelter support. AFAD has stated there is a total capacity of 5.064 beds which remains on standby should any need arise. In addition, 557 family sized tents, 40 general use large scale tents, 204 container living units as well as 42 portable toilets have been deployed to the fire affected areas by AFAD.   

According to the latest statements made by the Ministry of Health of the Republic of Turkey, 8 people have lost their lives as a result of the fires. 

Breakdown of the continuing wildfires according to provinces are as follows (Source: Ministry of Agriculture and Forestry of the Republic of Turkey):

- 21 wildfires have affected the Manavgat and Gündoğmuş districts of Antalya / 2 fires are still raging, 
- 14 wildfires have affected the Marmaris, Köyceğiz, Milas, Kavaklıdere, Yılanlı and Seydikemer districts of Muğla / 7 fires are still raging,
- 2 wildfires have affected the Karacasu district of Aydın / 1 fire is still raging,
- 3 wildfires have affected the Sütçüler and Eğirdir districts of Isparta / 2 fires are still raging,
- 4 wildfires have affected the Tavas and Güney districts of Denizli / 2 fires are still raging. 

The Minister of Foreign Affairs of the Republic of Turkey, Mevlüt ÇAVUŞOĞLU has stated that high wind velocity continues to complicate firefighting efforts in the affected areas. 

The average temperature in Antalya and Muğla provinces being 40 degrees celcius with high winds and record low humidity are further complicating efforts to bring the wildfires under control.

contacts.name: Anıl Türken

field_reports.description: A total of 132 wildfires have affected 36 different provinces in Turkey. The fires started on 28.07.2021 and continue to rage mainly in the Mediterranean and Aegean regions of Turkey. The main provinces that have been affected are Antalya, Adana, Mersin, Muğla and Osmaniye. According to reports by the Ministry of Agriculture and Forestry of the Republic of Turkey, 125 of the 132 wildfires have been brought under control through the determined efforts of the Ministry of Agriculture and Forestry, the Disaster and Emergency Management Authority (AFAD) as well as Metropolitan and Local Municipalities. More than 5,000 personnel, 51 helicopters, 16 aircraft fire extinguishers, 850 mobile water tankers, 9 aerial reconnaissance drones as well as more than 150 heavy machinery of various kinds have been deployed to battle the raging fires. The Disaster and Emergency Management Authority (AFAD) has indicated that 8 people have lost their lives as a result of the fires. The Minister of Health of the Republic of Turkey, Dr. Fahrettin Koca has stated a total of 869 people have sought hospital treatment, having been subsequently successfully treated and released from hospital. In addition the treatment of 47 people are continuing to be undertaken at a number of hospitals. The Ministry of Health has dispatched 44 ambulances in Muğla and 34 ambulances in Antalya, with health services continuing uninterrupted in other provinces affected by the fires. Breakdown of the wildfires according to provinces are as follows: Muğla - 10 wildfires (4 still raging, 6 brought under control), Antalya 15 wildfires (2 still raging, 13 brought under control), Adana – 22 wildfires (22 brought under control), Isparta 1 wildfire (still raging), Mersin 9 wildfires (9 brought under control), Izmir 9 wildfires (9 brought under control), Kahramanmaraş 8 wildfires (8 brought under control), Manisa 6 wildfires (6 brought under control), Kastamonu 5 wildfires (5 brought under control), Osmaniye 5 wildfires (5 brought under control), Balıkesir 3 wildfires (3 brought under control), Hatay 3 wildfires (3 brought under control), Kütahya 3 wildfires (3 brought under control), Sakarya 3 wildfires (3 brought under control), Bursa 2 wildfires (2 brought under control), Çorum 2 wildfires (2 brought under control), Diyarbakır 2 wildfires (2 brought under control), Istanbul 2 wildfires (2 brought under control), Kırklareli 2 wildfires (2 brought under control), Kocaeli 2 wildfires (2 brought under control) in addition to sporadic fires brought under control in the provinces of Aydın, Bilecik, Bingöl, Bitlis, Çanakkale, Çankırı, Denizli, Edirne, Isparta, Karaman, Kayseri, Kilis, Uşak, Samsun, Şanlıurfa and Tunceli. The average temperature in Antalya and Muğla provinces being 40 degrees celcius with high winds and record low humidity are further complicating efforts to bring the wildfires under control.

The forest fires, which first started in Manavgat district of Antalya on 28 July and are still continuing throughout Turkey, and affects different areas in Adana, Antalya, Denizli, Isparta, Mersin, Muğla and Osmaniye provinces. The fires that took place adversely affected the forests and settlements. Many neighborhoods and villages were evacuated due to fires. Many animals perished in the middle of the flames.

On July 13, 2021, a devastating flood struck the district of Güneysu in Rize, located in Turkey’s Black Sea region. Heavy rains led to severe flooding and landslides, significantly damaging homes, roads, and infrastructure. Tragically, six people lost their lives, while dozens suffered minor injuries and hundreds were evacuated from their homes. Rescue teams were deployed immediately to assist those stranded and conduct search and rescue operations. The flood highlighted the region's vulnerability to natural disasters and underscored the need for improved disaster preparedness.

Tragically, six people lost their lives, while dozens suffered minor injuries and hundreds were evacuated from their homes. field_reports.description: There are at least 17 buildings sustaining heavy damage in İzmir. 4  buildings totally collapsed. More than 2.955 aftershocks were recorded after the Earthquake as of 17:00, 09 November, and they cause fear among people. The tidal wave hit the coast of the Seferishisar District of İzmir. The people traumatized by stress and fear prefer to stay out of their homes in İzmir.

contacts.name: İbrahim Özer
contacts.title: Deputy Director General for Disaster Management

field_reports.description:
On the 22nd of August 2020, flash floods occurred as the result of excessive rainfall In Turkey’s Black Sea province of Giresun province.
First response teams, food, and shelter materials from Turkish Red Crescent's Erzurum, Elazığ, Ankara Regional Disaster Management Centers were dispatched to Giresun during the initial minutes of the natural disaster. 
Turkish Red Crescent General Manager and Deputy General Manager of Disaster Management coordinate response activities in the region.

On the 31st of August, the Disaster and Emergency Management Presidency (AFAD) shared the latest situation in Giresun as follows:
'' Search and rescue and recovery activities in Giresun continue with a team of 3,627 and 1270 vehicles from AFAD, Gendarmerie, Police, Coast Guard, 112 Emergency Services, DSI, Municipality, Fire Department, Highways Department, UMKE, Turkish Red Crescent, AKUT (search and rescue), IHH and other NGO staffs .
field_reports.summary: Flash Floods hit northeastern Turkey's Giresun province

results.name: Flash Floods Hit Northeastern Turkey's Giresun province
results.summary:
On the 22nd of August 2020, flash floods occurred as the result of excessive rainfall In Turkey’s Black Sea province of Giresun province. First response teams, food, and shelter materials from Turkish Red Crescent's Erzurum, Elazığ, Ankara Regional Disaster Management Centers were dispatched to Giresun during the initial minutes of the natural disaster. Turkish Red Crescent General Manager and Deputy General Manager of Disaster Management coordinate response activities in the region.

 

On the 31st of August, the Disaster and Emergency Management Presidency (AFAD) shared the latest situation in Giresun as follows: '' Search and rescue and recovery activities in Giresun continue with a team of 3,627 and 1270 vehicles from AFAD, Gendarmerie, Police, Coast Guard, 112 Emergency Services, DSI, Municipality, Fire Department, Highways Department, UMKE, Turkish Red Crescent, AKUT, IHH, and other NGO staffs.
